citations.narrative:
* Official ID was missing for three dogs that were recorded on the USDA form 7005.
Records provide a source of information that can be used to identify every animal. Complete and accurate records are
needed to ensure each animal's identity can be known with certainty and to facilitate the ability to trace all animals. The
applicant shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information
concerning all dogs purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of.

* Documentation of the program of exercise for 24 dogs could not be found at time of inspection. Exercise is necessary for
the physical health and well-being of the dogs. All dogs must be allowed exercise as outlined unless otherwise exempted
by the attending veterinarian. The exercise plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The applicant must
develop an exercise plan with the attending veterinarian that documents the frequency, method, and duration of exercise
for each animal. It must address dogs being housed singly and in groups, methods, and period of providing exercise
opportunity and exemptions. The applicant must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with
the opportunity for exercise.

* The USDA Vet Care form 7002 A was incomplete. Under the vaccination schedule for 24 dogs, no plan when
vaccinations would be given for Parvovirus, Distemper, Rabies, Leptospirosis, Hepatitis and Bordetella had been
recorded. Under parasite control program, the applicant had recorded Nexguard, sprays and spray premise for fleas and
ticks. A plan for sampling the number or percentage of dogs that would be tested for heartworms and fecal floats was not
recorded. Heartworm and fecal float testing are done to ensure that there are no internal parasites. Giving annual rabies
vaccinations are important because it is much easier to prevent this deadly disease. The applicant must ensure that all
dogs are receiving vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs (including rabies, parvovirus, and
distemper) and there is sampling and treatment plan in place for parasites and other pests (including fleas, worms,
coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian.

* The USDA form 7002 A was incomplete. Under the preventive care and treatment care to be maintained for 24 dogs, it
only states “every three months evaluate and what is necessary”. Care and treatment of the hair coat, nails, eyes, ears,
skin, and teeth are necessary for the overall health of the dogs. Outlining what routine care will be provided is essential to
the health and wellbeing of the dogs. When the program of vet care is missing information on how the applicant provides
for the health and well-being of all dogs on the premise it is not considered to be adequate veterinary care. It also must
include when the veterinarian will be consulted. The applicant must consult with the attending veterinarian to develop a
preventative care and treatment plans to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and
healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class A license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 7/29/24 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.75(a)(1)(vi) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
* Official ID was missing for three dogs that were recorded on the USDA form 7005. 
Records provide a source of information that can be used to identify every animal. Complete and accurate records are 
needed to ensure each animal's identity can be known with certainty and to facilitate the ability to trace all animals. The 
applicant shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information 
concerning all dogs purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under 
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of. 
3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
* Documentation of the program of exercise for 24 dogs could not be found at time of inspection. Exercise is necessary for 
the physical health and well-being of the dogs. All dogs must be allowed exercise as outlined unless otherwise exempted 
by the attending veterinarian. The exercise plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The applicant must 
develop an exercise plan with the attending veterinarian that documents the frequency, method, and duration of exercise 
for each animal. It must address dogs being housed singly and in groups, methods, and period of providing exercise 
opportunity and exemptions. The applicant must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with 
the opportunity for exercise. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
* The USDA Vet Care form 7002 A was incomplete. Under the vaccination schedule for 24 dogs, no plan when 
vaccinations would be given for Parvovirus, Distemper, Rabies, Leptospirosis, Hepatitis and Bordetella had been 
recorded. Under parasite control program, the applicant had recorded Nexguard, sprays and spray premise for fleas and 
ticks. A plan for sampling the number or percentage of dogs that would be tested for heartworms and fecal floats was not 
recorded. Heartworm and fecal float testing are done to ensure that there are no internal parasites. Giving annual rabies 
vaccinations are important because it is much easier to prevent this deadly disease. The applicant must ensure that all 
dogs are receiving vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs (including rabies, parvovirus, and 
distemper) and there is sampling and treatment plan in place for parasites and other pests (including fleas, worms, 
coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian.

3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
* The USDA form 7002 A was incomplete. Under the preventive care and treatment care to be maintained for 24 dogs, it 
only states “every three months evaluate and what is necessary”. Care and treatment of the hair coat, nails, eyes, ears, 
skin, and teeth are necessary for the overall health of the dogs. Outlining what routine care will be provided is essential to 
the health and wellbeing of the dogs. When the program of vet care is missing information on how the applicant provides 
for the health and well-being of all dogs on the premise it is not considered to be adequate veterinary care. It also must 
include when the veterinarian will be consulted. The applicant must consult with the attending veterinarian to develop a 
preventative care and treatment plans to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and 
healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class A license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 7/29/24 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and 
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
